page.title: Work and Life in the Mobile Society/Business Impact/Relationships

revision.text:
{{hiddenh3|How have working relationships changed with the rise in mobility?}}
Becoming more and more dependent on IT and electronic communications, and driven by the benefit of saving office and travel costs, many companies have closed their offices and told their employees to be mobile workers. For these mobile workers, work is no longer just somewhere to go to, but something they do, wherever they are. This also raises a new managerial issue regarding how working relationships have changed with the increase in worker mobility.
==Definition== Firstly let us look at the definition of working relationship. Working relationship is defined as "an interpersonal relationship that is task-based, non-trivial, and of continuing duration" (Gabarro, 1990, p. 81). This means that working relationship is interpersonal relationships, in that they are based upon the shared goal of task achievement.
==Relations with Management== One major issue with respect to the working relationship in mobile workplace is managers who work with mobile workers must be results-oriented rather than process-driven. That is, they need to be comfortable seeing only what mobile workers get done and not what they're doing moment to moment. Another issue related to the working relationship in mobile workplace is mobile staff must form supportive relationships promptly. For example, mobile Working groups were more often made up of digital employees from all around the country, some times from all over the world, who never meet each other before. To work effectively, they must work in the bases of mutual support first, without any delay. Meanwhile they can develop relationship of affiliation and intimacy along with working.
==Worker Identification== Other issues such as mobile workers feel a weakened sense of identification with their organizations all arise from the special feature of the mobile working. The feature of mobile workers is they work at anywhere any time. This means that managers can’t monitor employees’ work before their eyes. This may cause managerial problems such as loss management, over-management, and lack of support to workers
This feature also can cause problems between co-workers, because getting to know, trust, and become comfortable with one’s project team members may take time. This can reduce the productivity and efficiency. Particularly troubling is the loss of informal and spontaneous work-related discussion. Brainstorming and unplanned interactions with coworkers can no longer be taken for granted.
==Eliminating Drawbacks== To strengthen the advantages and eliminate the drawbacks, managers must support the mobile workers mentally and technically without cramping their freedom and creativity. Managers may have to give up some controls but offer high level of trust, respect; Besides, they must pay close attention to communication styles and content; be able to empathize with workers whom they don’t see often in order to know when someone is under stress or is feeling isolated from the team; Furthermore, they must provide the up-date information about the organization to mobile workers in order to develop and maintain employees’ sense of organizational belonging and commitment.
To maximize the mobile working benefit, mobile workers must take more initiatives to maintain, nurture and enhance their relationship with one anther. Colleagues should develop the ability to establish mutual trust and respect; they should create the opportunity to engage in regular social interactions with their coworkers; they must be willing to be influenced, share important information, fulfill promises, and listen.
In addition to the above measures, mobile workers also should: 1) Be proactive in maintaining contact with their organizations. 2) Schedule informal lunches and formal meeting to increase face to face contacts. 3) Don’t restrict formal topics. Include some informal things such as family and kids in your talk. 4) Share photos, IT tips, jokes with others just like in the office.
==Future== As the research firm IDC claims, the number of mobile workers is increasing faster than stationary workers and mobile workers are more productive. However, companies, managers, mobile workers need to pay special attention to managing the working relationship properly, in order to realize the benefits. Besides, research also shows that the personal face to face contact is critical in mobility. Like a mobile worker said, “No matter how much technology is available, we are people. We are not robots and we are not computer databanks.
==References== * http://newsroom.cisco.com/dlls/2007/eKits/MobileWorkforce_071807.pdf A study: understanding and managing the mobile workforce. * http://jcmc.indiana.edu/vol10/issue4/cho.html The Use of Instant Messaging in Working Relationship Development: A Case Study * http://eric.ed.gov/ERICWebPortal/custom/portlets/recordDetails/detailmini.jsp?_nfpb=true * Social Connectivity in the Mobile Workplace. Workscape 21: The Ecology of New Ways of Working. * http://www.hrworld.com/features/trends-managing- Trends: Managing the Mobile Worker By David Hakala on January 29, 2008/ * http://www.wbdg.org The Changing Nature of Organizations, Work, and Workplace by Judith Heerwagen, Ph.D., J.H. Heerwagen & Associates Kevin Kelly and Kevin Kampschroer, U.S. General Services Administration
{{BookCat}}

== Join Us! == {{#ifeq:"{{NAMESPACE}}"|"User talk"| Hello and '''[[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome]]''' to [[Wikibooks]], a collection of open-content textbooks! You should consider [[Special:Userlogin|creating an account or logging in]]. Here are some advantages: * The use of a username of your choice. * Greater security and privacy, as your IP address will be hidden from most users. * You get your own personal user page and talk page, instead of having to share it. * [[Special:Contributions/{{PAGENAME}}|Your contributions]] will be recognized as your own, and not confused with anyone else's. * The use of your own watchlist which shows when pages you are interested in have been edited. * Your opinions carry greater weight in the [[Wikibooks:Decision making|decision making process]]. * You become a recognized member of the Wikibooks community. * Creating an account is easy and only takes a few minutes of your time, especially given the benefits. We hope that you choose to become a Wikibookian and [[Special:Userlogin|create an account]].
Feel free to ask any questions on my talk page or in the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading room]].
Be sure to sign your posts and comments on talk pages with four tildes (~~~~), this will let other editors know you said it.
|

{{tw-adopt}}{{dewikify}} [[Image:Saxophone reeds-alto, tenor.jpeg|thumb|Saxophone reeds|200 px]]
== Wooden Reed Care and Bacteria ==
=== Introduction ===
Due to their natural composition, wooden musical [[reed (instrument)|reeds]] may hold bacteria or mold, which can affect one’s health and the quality of sound produced. Some of the basic instruments that use wooden reeds include the [[clarinet]], [[saxophone]], [[oboe]], and [[bassoon]]. Proper care of reeds will extend their longevity and control bacterial growth.
=== Reed Care === ===== Reed Preparation =====
Wooden reeds must be moistened prior to playing. Many musicians place the reed in their mouths to moisten them with [[saliva]]. In preparing the reed for playing, water is less corrosive than saliva. Soaking a reed in water for about five minutes is a good alternative to saliva. It also reduces the chance of food particles damaging the reed <ref>Stambler, David. "Single Reed Reed Basics." 2005. Penn State University. http://www.capitolquartet.com/admin/pdf/Reedbasics.pdf.</ref>. However, soaking reeds in already humid weather may cause them to become water logged; extreme environments can damage reeds. They should not be kept too dry or too wet, or they will become warped <ref name="Williams">Williams, Floyd. "Reeds: How to Care for Them and How to Improve Their Repsonse." ''Australian Clarinet and Saxophone''. June 2003: 11-12</ref>.
Dark spots on new reeds are not an indication that the reeds are poor, but if the dark spots have formed after several uses, it may be an indication of mold growth. Therefore, it is also suggested that one soak their reed in [[hydrogen peroxide]]. Five minutes a day is sufficient to keep the reed clean from [[bacteria]] and [[mold]]. It should also kill any salivary [[enzymes]] that may have collected on the reed while playing. If hydrogen peroxide is not available, musicians need to be sure to rinse the reed in running water and then dry it before storing.
[[Image:Klarinet-jeziček.jpg|300 px|thumb|left|Reed Case]]
===== Reed Storage =====
Reed storage affects the reed life and may help or hinder bacterial and mold growth. Putting a dirty reed in a reed case just allows mold and bacteria to grow in the case every time the reed is placed in it. Mold can also grow if reeds are kept in a tightly sealed container in [[humidity|humid]] environments. Every time the container is opened moisture is caught inside, allowing mold to grow <ref name="Williams"/>. Storage in a cool, dry environment, like a refrigerator, helps to slow microbial growth <ref name="Bryan">Bryan, A. H. (1960). Band instruments harbor germs. Music Educators Journal, 46(5), 84-85.</ref>. [[Light]] and [[ultraviolet]] radiation will not damage the reed structure unless exposure time is excessive or if radiation levels are high <ref name="Casadonte">Casadonte, Donald Jay The clarinet reed: An introduction to its biology, chemistry, and physics. Diss. The Ohio State University, 1995. Dissertations & Theses: Full Text. ProQuest. Harold B. Lee Library, Provo, Utah. 11 Jul. 2008 http://www.proquest.com/</ref>. A cool cabinet with a [[desiccant]], such as [[calcium sulfate]], can also serve as a good storage area. Not only do cooler environments discourage bacterial growth, but there are almost no harmful effects on a normal reed.
Heat can have a damaging effect on the chemical authenticity of the reed. Soaking the reed in nearly boiling water is not recommended for cleaning. The [[hydrogen bonds]] begin to break down between 60 degrees C and 80 degrees C. At 100 degrees C much of the molecular structure is lost. Heating dry wood can also cause splitting <ref name="Casadonte"/>. When not being used, reeds should be kept covered. There are many products available specifically for reed storage.
===== Personal Hygiene and Reed Care =====
Reed longevity is affected by the musician’s personal hygiene habits. As many band directors encourage, eating prior to playing is not good for one’s instrument or for one’s own health. Old food is a gold mine for bacterial growth, especially microbial flora. Appropriately, one might [[toothbrush|brush their teeth]], [[Dental floss|floss]], and use [[mouthwash]], before and after playing to lower risks of illness <ref name="Bryan"/>. It should be realized that using a reed while sick with a [[Common cold|cold]] increases mucous discharge from the [[throat]] and [[lungs]] onto the reed. This will more quickly strip [[hemicellulose]] from the reed. Hemicellulose maintains the reed’s ability to hold water<ref name="Casadonte"/>. Using a reed while sick quickly decreases the reed’s ability to absorb water; this is irreversible damage. Also, using a reed while sick increases the chance for reinfection. It is common that musicians just use old spent reeds while ill to keep from damaging good reeds.
=== The effect of Saliva on Reeds ===
===== pH Levels =====
Normally, saliva is slightly [[acidic]] and has a [[pH]] less than 7, but it can vary between 6 and 8. The pH inside the mouth depends on the salival flow rate because the higher the flow rate of saliva the more salival [[bicarbonates]] are present. Bicarbonates in the saliva raise the pH inside the mouth. When there is no or low saliva flow, also known as [[xerostomia]], the pH inside the mouth is around 6. When salival flow rate is high the pH is about 8. During a concert, if a musician is suffering from xerostomia, also known as dry mouth, the saliva pH is expected to be [[acidic]] <ref name="Casadonte"/>.
Nervousness in concert situations can also lead to xerostomia, but more importantly nervousness can cause [[Hyperventilation|rapid breathing]]. This increases [[carbon dioxide]] (CO<sub>2</sub> ) flow out of the body and causes [[respiratory alkalosis]]. The decrease in CO<sub>2</sub> affects the amount of [[bicarbonates]] available. Salivary bicarbonates are synthesized from CO<sub>2</sub>. The less CO<sub>2</sub> available, the fewer bicarbonates can be synthesized; therefore, the pH drops<ref name="Casadonte"/>. Under this condition it is wise to use salival flow stimulants. Continually changing the pH environment the reed encounters damages the reed. If the pH level inside the mouth can be kept at rehearsal level, the life of the reed will increase.
Consequently, the environment for regular rehearsal differs. The musician may not be as nervous, and they might be holding their breath more to play. Holding one’s breath increases CO<sub>2</sub>, also known as [[respiratory acidosis]]. Therefore, saliva is expected to be more alkaline. In a reeds life, it is more likely to face alkaline environments because rehearsals occur more often than concerts. The alkaline environment increases the amount of hemicellulose stripped from the reed matrix <ref name="Casadonte"/>. Although hemicellulose is depleted, it is better for the reed to remain in an overall consistent environment.
[[File:Chemical precipitation diagram.svg|thumb|left|Chemical Percipitation|275 px]]
===== Contaminants in Saliva =====
Even though salival pH decreases the hemicelluloses coating on reeds, it has little effect on the reed matrix compared to the contaminants found in saliva. [[Amine]]s and [[glycoproteins]] have been found in the reed matrix: salivary mucosins, Proline-rich Glycoproteins, alpha-amylases, peroxidase, Carbonic Anhydrase, Fucose-rich glycoproteins, Immunoglobulin, Kallikrein, Lactoferrin, and Fibronectrin<ref name="Casadonte"/>.
Oral bacterium already in one’s mouth removes the sugar containing components from glycoproteins in saliva. This removal of sugar forms a [[precipitate]] or a non-soluble by product. The protein precipitate formed in saliva is normally rich in [[calcium]] and low in [[solubility]]. Also, [[alpha-amylase]] contains a significant level of [[sialic acid]]. When alpha-amylase combines with saliva, the enzymes [[hydrolyze]] and release the sialic acid, forming another water insoluble precipitate <ref name="Casadonte"/>. These two precipitates combine to form an impenetrable layer on the reed, which prevent the reed from fully hydrating. In time, the reed will become stiff and brittle.
=== Types of Bacteria found in reeds ===
Streptococcal bacteria have been found living inside the walls of water-conducting [[xylem]] cells in spent reeds. Streptococcal bacterium is a common bacterium that causes illness to the throat, including [[sore throat]] and [[strep throat]]<ref name="Horaud"/>.
Also the common bacterium, Staphalcoccus Epidermitis, completely covers the reed. It is also found all over the mouth and hands on virtually everyone; therefore, it is innocuous. Staphalcoccus Epidermitis is known as one of the bacteria which remove the sugars from saliva, which causes the deposition of sialic acid. This type of bacteria becomes dormant in the absence of water<ref name="Casadonte"/>. Drying reeds before storing will help stop the growth of Staphalcoccus Epidermitis.
=== The Effect of Bacteria on Reeds ===
Bacterium affects the playability of the reed in three ways. First, it adds mass to the reed tip. A bacterial coating actually dampens the vibrating reed, causing it to play at lower [[frequencies]]. Secondly, it reduces the reed’s range of motion and bending. This will decrease the reeds ability to maintain sound. Lastly, it changes the overall shape of the reed, which directly affects the [[tone]] quality<ref name="Casadonte"/>.
=== The Effect of Reed Bacteria on the Body ===
The bacteria found covering reeds may cause [[respiratory]] infections such as [[colds]], [[influenza]], [[pneumonia]], [[tuberculosis]], herpes fibrilis ([[cold sores]]), and other rare diseases. However, contact is necessary for the transfer of microbial infection. The airborne organisms are known to be virtually harmless. Infection will not spread between musicians unless there is contact with the bacteria <ref name="Bryan"/>.
[[Image:Streptococcal pharyngitis.jpg|thumb|Streptococcal Pharyngitis|300 px]]
Specifically, streptococci can cause varying levels of infections from mild to life-threatening. Starting in the 1980’s, [[group A streptococci]] have increased in prevalence and have been the cause of [[rheumatic fever]] and other invasive infections <ref name="Horaud">Horaud T., Bouvet A., Leclercq R., Montclos H. d. and Sicard M. ''Streptococci and The Host''. New York: Plenum Press. 1997: 255, 537.</ref>. The [[mucous membranes]] found in the [[nose]] and [[throat]] are primary sites for infection and transmission of group A streptococci <ref name="Horaud"/>. The mucus membranes are in direct contact with the reed during playing; therefore, if infection does occur it is likely it will derive from the group A streptococci.
When group A streptococcal infects the throat, it is also known as [[streptococcal pharyngitis]], or strep throat. Redness, trouble swallowing, swelling of regional [[lymph nodes]], and localized pain are common complaints of streptococcal pharyngitis. [[Leukocytosis]], an abnormally high white blood level, is a common reaction to the infection. Streptococcal pharyngitis is most prevalent during colder seasons. Many marching bands play on cold nights at football games. Exposing musicians to such weather and bacterium may increase the likelihood of infection<ref name="Wannamaker">Wannamaker, LW. "Differences between streptococcal infections of the throat and of the skin. Part I." ''New England Journal of Medicine.'' 282 (1970): 23-31.</ref>.
== Notes ==

[[Image:Crystal Clear app korganizer.png|20px]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for freely-licensed collaboratively-developed [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].'''
You don't need technical skills in order to contribute here. '''[[WB:BOLD|Be bold]]''' contributing here and ''[[WB:AGF|assume good faith]]'' for the intentions of others. Remember, this is a ''[[w:wiki|wiki]]'', so you're allowed to change just about anything, and changes can be made easily. Come [[WB:HELP|introduce yourself]] to everyone, and let us know what interests you.
[[Image:Icon apps query.svg|20px]] '''Getting help'''
* Remember, every edit is saved, so if you make mistakes, you can [[Help:How to revert a page to an earlier version|revert]] to an earlier version if needed. * Get help from the community in the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading room]] or in our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * We tag pages with various [[WB:TM|message templates]], such as {{tlx|query}}, to let editors know what needs to be improved. To learn more about these, ask at [[WB:PROJECTS|the projects reading room]]. * You cannot upload an image until you have been a member for at least '''4 days'''. If your upload is tagged with {{tlx|nld}}, {{tlx|bfu}}, or {{tlx|nfur}}, please read the template message as it explains the violation of [[WB:MEDIA|our media policy]]. Please be sure to provide the required {{tlx|information}}: a [[WB:ICT|license tag]] and source citation are always required; fair use images require a {{tlx|fair use rationale}}. Get help in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]]. | style="padding:0em 0.5em 0em 0.5em;" | | style="width:45%; vertical-align:top; border:1px solid #abd5f5; background-color:#f1f5fc;" |
[[Image:Transmission icon.png|20px]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please [[:w:Wikipedia:Sign your posts on talk pages|sign your name]] on discussion pages by typing ~~~~ * If you're coming here from Wikipedia, you should read [[WB:WFW|our primer for Wikipedians]] to get up-to-speed quickly. * '''Please make sure you follow our [[WB:NP|naming policy]]''' - modules should be named like Book Title/Chapter Title. * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
[[Image:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (only become available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To get a page deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason for requesting deletion''}} to the top of the page. * If something you wrote was deleted, please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:VFD|VFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:VFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
Thanks  '''— [[User:Mike.lifeguard|Mike.lifeguard]]''' | [[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|talk]] 18:46, 26 November 2008 (UTC)
|- |align=right colspan=3|(P.S. Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?) |} :Did that import you requested: [[Transwiki:Wooden reed care]]  '''— [[User:Mike.lifeguard|Mike.lifeguard]]''' | [[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|talk]] 18:46, 26 November 2008 (UTC) == Bulletin Board v's Reading Room == The bulletin board is for announcements rather than discussion of ideas, especially as nobody reads the bulletin board. Your "announcement" is I think better placed in the Reading Room ([[Wikibooks:Reading room/Projects|here]]) where others can read and comment on it. I meant to move it last time, rather than just reverting without explanation, but it appears I didn't - sorry. [[User:QuiteUnusual|'''QU''']] [[User talk:QuiteUnusual|TalkQu]] 15:16, 3 October 2012 (UTC)

revision.comment: /* Oxygen Binding Curve (Hemoglobin vs Myoglobin) */general cleanup, typos fixed: of it's → of its (2), , → , using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
==Oxygen Binding Curve (Hemoglobin vs Myoglobin)== Oxygen binding to iron in the heme group pulls part of the electron density from the ferrous ion to the oxygen molecule. It is important to leave the [[Structural Biochemistry/Myoglobin|myoglobin]] in the dioxygen form rather than superoxide form when the oxygen is released because the superoxide can be generated by itself to have a new form that gives negative effect on many biological materials, and also the superoxide prevents the iron ion from binding to the oxygen in its ferric state (Metmyoglobin). Superoxide and superoxide-derived oxygen species are so reactive compared to the stable O2 molecule that they could have a destructive effect both within the cell and in its environment. A distal histidine residue in [[Structural Biochemistry/Myoglobin|myoglobin]] regulates the reactivity of the heme group to make it more suitable for oxygen binding. It does this by H-bonding with the oxygen molecule; the additional electron density of the oxygen molecule makes the H-bond unusually strong and therefore even more effective as a stabilizing agent.
An oxygen-binding curve is a plot that shows fractional saturation versus the concentration of oxygen. By definition, fractional saturation indicates the presence of binding sites that have oxygen. Fractional saturation can range from zero (all sites are empty) to one (all sites are filled). The concentration of oxygen is determined by partial pressure.
[[Structural Biochemistry/Hemoglobin|Hemoglobin]]'s oxygen affinity is relatively weak compared to [[Structural Biochemistry/Myoglobin|myoglobin]] 's affinity for oxygen. [[Structural Biochemistry/Hemoglobin|Hemoglobin]]'s oxygen-binding curve forms in the shape of a sigmoidal curve. This is due to the cooperativity of the [[Structural Biochemistry/Hemoglobin|hemoglobin]]. As [[Structural Biochemistry/Hemoglobin|hemoglobin]] travels from the lungs to the tissues, the pH value of its surroundings decrease, and the amount of CO<sub>2</sub> that it reacts with increases. Both these changes causes the [[Structural Biochemistry/Hemoglobin|hemoglobin]] to lose it's affinity for oxygen, therefore making it drop the oxygen into the tissues. This causes the sigmoidal curve for [[Structural Biochemistry/Hemoglobin|hemoglobin]] in the oxygen-binding curve and proves it's cooperativity.
[[Image:oxygen binding curve.jpg]] [[Image:Oxygen binding curve with hemoglobin and myoglobin.jpg]]
This image shows [[Structural Biochemistry/Hemoglobin|hemoglobin]]'s oxygen binding affinity compared with [[Structural Biochemistry/Myoglobin|myoglobin]] 's affinity and the hypothetical curve that [[Structural Biochemistry/Hemoglobin|hemoglobin]] would have to follow if it did not show cooperativity. In this graph, you can see [[Structural Biochemistry/Hemoglobin|hemoglobin]]'s sigmoidal curve, how it starts out with a little less affinity than [[Structural Biochemistry/Myoglobin|myoglobin]], but comparable affinity to oxygen in the lungs. As the pressure drops and the [[Structural Biochemistry/Myoglobin|myoglobin]] and [[Structural Biochemistry/Hemoglobin|hemoglobin]] move towards the tissues, [[Structural Biochemistry/Myoglobin|myoglobin]] still attains it's high affinity for oxygen, while [[Structural Biochemistry/Hemoglobin|hemoglobin]], because of its cooperativity, suddenly loses it's affinity, therefore making it the better transporter of oxygen than [[Structural Biochemistry/Myoglobin|myoglobin]] . The gray curve, showing no cooperativity, shows that to have the low affinity for oxygen needed in the tissues, the [[Structural Biochemistry/Hemoglobin|hemoglobin]] would have started with a smaller affinity for oxygen, therefore making it less efficient in bringing oxygen in from the lungs.
==Oxygen Binding Curve for Hemoglobin== In red blood cells, the oxygen-binding curve for [[Structural Biochemistry/Hemoglobin|hemoglobin]] displays an “S” shaped called a sigmoidal curve. A sigmoidal curve shows that oxygen binding is cooperative; that is, when one site binds oxygen, the probability that the remaining unoccupied sites that will bind to oxygen will increase.
The importance of cooperative behavior is that it allows [[Structural Biochemistry/Hemoglobin|hemoglobin]] to be more efficient in transporting oxygen. For example, in the lungs, the [[Structural Biochemistry/Hemoglobin|hemoglobin]] is at a saturation level of 98%. However, when [[Structural Biochemistry/Hemoglobin|hemoglobin]] is present in the tissues and releases oxygen, the saturation level drops to 32%; thus, 66% of the potential oxygen-binding sites are involved in the transportation of oxygen.
Purified [[Structural Biochemistry/Hemoglobin|hemoglobin]] binds much more tightly to the oxygen, making it less useful in oxygen transport. The difference in characteristics is due to the presence of 2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate(2,3-BPG) in human blood, which acts as an allosteric effector. An allosteric effector binds in one site and affects binding in another. 2,3-BPG binds to a pocket in the T-state of [[Structural Biochemistry/Hemoglobin|hemoglobin]] and is released as it forms the R-state. The presence of 2,3-BPG means that more oxygen must be bound to the [[Structural Biochemistry/Hemoglobin|hemoglobin]] before the transition to the R-form is possible.
Other regulation such as the Bohr effect in [[Structural Biochemistry/Hemoglobin|hemoglobin]] can also be depicted via an oxygen-binding curve. By analyzing the oxygen-binding curve, one can observe that there is a proportional relationship between affinity of oxygen and pH level. As the pH level decreases, the affinity of oxygen in [[Structural Biochemistry/Hemoglobin|hemoglobin]] also decreases. Thus, as [[Structural Biochemistry/Hemoglobin|hemoglobin]] approaches a region of low pH, more oxygen is released. The chemical basis for this Bohr effect is due to the formation of two salt bridges of the quaternary structure. One of the salt bridges is formed by the interaction between Beta Histidine 146 (the carboxylate terminal group) and Alpha Lysine 40. This connection will help to orient the histidine residue to also interact in another salt bridge formation with the negatively charged aspartate 94. The second bridge is form with the aid of an additional proton on the histidine residue.
As carbon dioxide diffuses into red blood cells, it reacts with water inside to form carbonic acid, which drops the pH and stabilizes the T state.
[[Image:PH on hemoglobin.JPG]]
An oxygen-binding curve can also show the effect of carbon dioxide presence in [[Structural Biochemistry/Hemoglobin|hemoglobin]]. The regulation effect by carbon dioxide is similar to Bohr effect. A comparison of the effect of the absence and presence of carbon dioxide in [[Structural Biochemistry/Hemoglobin|hemoglobin]] revealed that [[Structural Biochemistry/Hemoglobin|hemoglobin]] is more efficient at transporting oxygen from tissues to lungs when carbon dioxide is present. The reason for this efficiency is that carbon dioxide also decreases the affinity of [[Structural Biochemistry/Hemoglobin|hemoglobin]] for oxygen. The addition of carbon dioxide forces the pH to drop, which then causes the affinity of [[Structural Biochemistry/Hemoglobin|hemoglobin]] to oxygen to decrease. This is extremely evident in the tissues, where the carbon dioxide stored in the tissues are released into the blood stream, then undergoes a reaction that releases H<sup>+</sup> into the blood stream, increasing acidity and dropping the pH level.
{{BookCat}}

You don't need technical skills in order to contribute here. '''[[WB:BOLD|Be bold]]''' contributing here and ''[[WB:AGF|assume good faith]]'' for the intentions of others. Remember, this is a ''[[w:wiki|wiki]]'', so you're allowed to change just about anything, and changes can be made easily. Come [[WB:HELP|introduce yourself]] to everyone, and let us know what interests you.
[[Image:Icon apps query.svg|20px]] '''Getting help'''
* Remember, every edit is saved, so if you make mistakes, you can [[Help:How to revert a page to an earlier version|revert]] to an earlier version if needed. * Get help from the community in the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading room]] or in our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * We tag pages with various [[WB:TM|message templates]], such as {{tlx|query}}, to let editors know what needs to be improved. To learn more about these, ask at [[WB:PROJECTS|the projects reading room]]. * You cannot upload an image until you have been a member for at least '''4 days'''. If your upload is tagged with {{tlx|nld}}, {{tlx|bfu}}, or {{tlx|nfur}}, please read the template message as it explains the violation of [[WB:MEDIA|our media policy]]. Please be sure to provide the required {{tlx|information}}: a [[WB:ICT|license tag]] and source citation are always required; fair use images require a {{tlx|fair use rationale}}. Get help in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]]. | style="padding:0em 0.5em 0em 0.5em;" | | style="width:45%; vertical-align:top; border:1px solid #abd5f5; background-color:#f1f5fc;" |
[[Image:Transmission icon.png|20px]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please [[:w:Wikipedia:Sign your posts on talk pages|sign your name]] on discussion pages by typing ~~~~ * If you're coming here from Wikipedia, you should read [[WB:WFW|our primer for Wikipedians]] to get up-to-speed quickly. * '''Please make sure you follow our [[WB:NP|naming policy]]''' - modules should be named like Book Title/Chapter Title. * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
[[Image:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (only become available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To get a page deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason for requesting deletion''}} to the top of the page. * If something you wrote was deleted, please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:VFD|VFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:VFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
Thanks  '''— [[User:Mike.lifeguard|Mike.lifeguard]]''' | [[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|talk]] 19:56, 26 November 2008 (UTC)
|- |align=right colspan=3|(P.S. Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?) |} == Copyright problems with [[:Image:Geneticcode.jpeg|Image:Geneticcode.jpeg]] == {{mbox|type=warning|msg= Thank you for uploading [[:Image:Geneticcode.jpeg|Image:Geneticcode.jpeg]]. However it is missing information needed for compliance with [[w:copyright|copyright law]] and Wikibooks' [[WB:MEDIA|media policy]]. This and other files you have uploaded may soon be deleted unless the '''copyright permissions''' and '''source''' can be determined. If you know this information, then please add the correct [[WB:ICT|templates]] to the [[:Image:Image:Geneticcode.jpeg|description page]] with the copyright and source information included; there is no need to upload it again. If you have any questions, feel free to contact me, or ask in the [[WB:HELP|assistance reading room]]. See {{UserImages}} for a complete list of your uploads which may get deleted soon.
Thank you.  '''— [[User:Mike.lifeguard|Mike.lifeguard]]''' | [[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|talk]] 19:56, 26 November 2008 (UTC)}} ==Use of Commons Images on Wikibooks== Hi, I notice that you seem to have downloaded images from Commons, then uploaded them to Wikibooks with different file names. Creating duplicate images like this is discouraged. There really is no need to do this as you can reference a file directly at Commons - just include the file / image name as if it was held locally on Wikibooks. Also, when you have uploaded them, you haven't included license data so they may be deleted. Therefore, I'm going to find the original Commons images and change the articles to reference those instead. Thanks. [[User:QuiteUnusual|'''Unusual? Quite''']] [[User talk:QuiteUnusual|TalkQu]] 14:31, 2 January 2009 (UTC) == Copyright problems with [[:Image:Tir.png|Image:Tir.png]] == {{mbox|type=warning|msg= Thank you for uploading [[:Image:Tir.png|Image:Tir.png]]. However it is missing information needed for compliance with [[w:copyright|copyright law]] and Wikibooks' [[WB:MEDIA|media policy]]. This and other files you have uploaded may soon be deleted unless the '''copyright permissions''' and '''source''' can be determined. If you know this information, then please add the correct [[WB:ICT|templates]] to the [[:Image:Image:Tir.png|description page]] with the copyright and source information included; there is no need to upload it again. If you have any questions, feel free to contact me, or ask in the [[WB:HELP|assistance reading room]]. See {{UserImages}} for a complete list of your uploads which may get deleted soon.
Thank you. [[User:QuiteUnusual|'''Unusual? Quite''']] [[User talk:QuiteUnusual|TalkQu]] 21:53, 2 January 2009 (UTC)}}

page.title: Mandarin Chinese Grammar for Pimsleur Students/Future tense

revision.text: {{Template:MCG}} == Future tense == The future tense is generally indicated by the [[Mandarin Chinese Grammar for Pimsleur Students/Non-adjectival stative verbs|auxiliary verb]] 要 / yào. {| style="background:gainsboro" cellpadding="3" cellspacing="5" |- | style="background:silver" | 要 || style="background:lightgrey" | yào || will, want |} {| cellpadding="3" cellspacing="5" |- || 我们要坐飞机去 ◦ || wŏmen yào zuò fēijī qù. || We will travel by airplane. |- || 我要现在吃午饭 ◦ || wŏ yào xiàn zài chī wŭfàn. || I am going to have lunch now. |- || 要几个小时 ? || yào jĭ ge xiăoshí? || How many hours is it going to be? |} [[Category:Mandarin Chinese Grammar for Pimsleur Students|Future tense]]

The Hero tab, like the heroes and heroins you will create, may look complicated at first, as if it was a monster itself and stand in the way of you creating your perfect game, but all in due time. We'll take this tab apart piece by piece.
==The Hero Area== See the area on the far left? Those are your heroes and heroines! These are the characters that you can create and customize, down to the last detail. The two main functions this serves are as follows:
*It creates a list of all of your heroes and heroins, and allows you to select any of them for editing and customization.
*It also allows you to create more simply by increasing the array size.
;Array size: An array is the amount of a category you would like to exist. Many are limited to 5000 of any object, so use sparingly! Items such as switches, variables, items, heroes, and even some events are limited by the array size.
==Name, Title, and Character Graphics== Now it's time to give your heroes and heroins some personality! These are the areas where, like in their names, allow you to change the name of your heroes/heroins, their titles, and what they'll look like during the course of the game. If you want someone to look like a ghost as they walk around, click "Transparent" next to their character sprite.
Under "Battle Sprite", there will be the picture of some battle sprites, and a scroll bar. You will go over those options in the [[RPG_Maker_2003/Animations2|Animations 2]] page.
==Options, Crit Hit, Min and Max Level, and Class== Such a big category of options! However, each is very basic and covers a minimal amount of options. The options area is a checklist, giving characters certain abilities, such as whether or not they can wield two weapons (Two Wpn), if they can't change equipment (Lock Eqp), if they can be controlled by artifical intelligence during battle (AI Control), or if they can have exceptional guarding abilities during battle (Mighty Grd).
The critical hit probability is exactly as it states; give them a chance to hit the enemies weakspot by changing the critical hit ratio. Want them to hit it a lot? Make the number lower. Is your hero/heroin really clumsy? Make it higher. Or, you can remove it completely.
The Minimum and Maximum Levels are the levels in which your characters are limited by. You can make them arrive in the game at a very high level, but not allow them to get much higher, or you can make them long lasting by giving them a low minimum level and a high maximum level. They are both limited at 1 and 99 as their lowest and highest.
The class is a different story though. This allows characters to be customized even more later in your games. If you feel one character is a soldier, give him/her that class. Don't worry though. You can have class changes later in the game.
==Base Statistics== [[Image:RPG004.jpg|500|left]]Now we're getting into some of the more complicated messes. These are the curves that you can create that make a character's leveling curve unique. If you want to change the base of a curve, simply double click the graphs. You will now see several tabs, labeled by the names of the different stats you can change, and buttons on the right. A complicated looking graph will be situated on the left.
Let's not worry about that right now. On the right, you'll see buttons labeled Outstanding, Above Average, Average, and Below Average. These are preset curves you can create for that specific character. Try clicking one of those buttons. See how the curve changes? You can use these to create general curves for characters, if you are kind of lazy.
Instead, this book suggests that you use the "Specify Endpoints" tab, and alter the "Accelerate Growth". First, you start with the amount you want your level 1 character to have of that stat, and then do the same with what you want your level 99 character to have. After you specify that, change the growth. You can make it where the character grows fast sooner, but starts slowing down as he/she gets higher in level, or make the character a late bloomer, and get more powerful later in the game. It's up to you.
If you're not satisfied with the graph, you might have to make it manually. You can do this by selecting the Level on the right, and changing the Maximum __ in accordance with your wishes. This might become a bit tedious after a while, but if you really want to do it manually, no one is stopping you. It could also have a bigger pay off.
Instead of manually entering the numbers, you can also click on the graph itself. Try clicking on some spot above the first bar. It should rise to where you clicked. The number underneath the Maximum __ should also change. This could make the task easier, but accuracy becomes a problem, since you have to be situated exactly above the bar you want to change. Otherwise, you can change a different bar, and ruin the perfect graph you had going.
==Experience Curve== This is even more complicated than the Base Statistics section above, and you must read this to understand how it works. You should see two tabs on the top of the new window after you click the "Experience Curve" button. One should say "Total Experience", and display a large list of green numbers, three sliders on the bottom, and a graph on the right.The second tab should say "Experience per Level", and instead of green numbers, should have a large list of blue numbers.
Unlike the "Base Stats" section of the Hero tab, there is no way to manually change the numbers, but with the knowledge you'll gain here, you should be able to manipulate the numbers enough to get what you want.
===Primary=== First, start off with the "Experience per Level" tab. This will help you understand what is going on. Otherwise, you will get confused with the numbers being displayed on the other tab. Also, blue is a lot easier on the eyes than green.
Set the Tertiary and Secondary sliders to 0 and 1, respectively. Now, set Primary to any number. Do you see something? As you should, the first number on the list should be the primary number you chose, plus 1. This allows you to set a base for your curve. You will always have this number in the experience curve you choose.
===Secondary=== This one is what caused the extra numbers you saw in the Primary test. Notice how it starts with 1 on level 1, and then increases by 1 every level? That is what characterizes the secondary curve. Start with Primary on 300. Now set Secondary to 2. Now set it to 3. Do you see the pattern? It will increase by the number you set it to every time the character becomes the respective level.
This is true for any number you give it. If at level 1, (with Primary still at 300) it is 400, then at level 2, it should be 500. Can you guess what the Secondary curve is set at?If you guessed 100, then you are correct.
===Tertiary=== This is probably the easiest curve to change and understand. In the most simple of terms, it adds what number you give it to EVERY LEVEL. If you give it a number of 5, then 5 will be added to every number on the list. Try it out with Primary set to 300 and Secondary set to 300. Now change the Tertiary to any number you choose. Notice how the numbers change in the exact same way? That is how the Tertiary curve works.
==Starting Equipment== Just as it states, the starting equipment is what the hero/heroin will start with at the beginning of the game. You can set the weapon, shield (this will be a second weapon if you chose Two Wpn in the options area), armor, helmet, and accessory of that particular hero/heroin.
You can change the kinds of equipment your hero/heroin can equip by changing them in the [[RPG_Maker_2003/Item|Item]] tab, which will be explained later.
==Unarmed Battle Animation== This is what your hero's/heroin's punch or kick will look like when they are unarmed, or without weapons. You can select any of the premade animations, or create your own in the [[RPG_Maker_2003/Animations|Animations]] tab, which will be explained later.
==Skill Progression== You know how certain RPGs, like Pokemon, have you gain skills or attacks as you gain levels? You can do the same here using the "Skill Progression" area. To add a skill, right click on where the first skill will be, and click on "Edit". Now, you can choose any skill you want, and tell it on which level your hero/heroin will learn it.
You can add and edit skills in the [[RPG_Maker_2003/Skill|Skill]] tab, which will be talked about later.
==Condition Resist and Attribute Resist== ;Condition: a condition is what affects your character during a battle, and if specified, after a battle. These can range anywhere from poison, to sleep, to death.
;Attribute: an attribute is the type of an attack or spell. This includes, but is not limited to, sword attacks, fire spells, or even fire-attributed swords.
These lists allow your character to live during certain attacks and falter during others. Let's assume that your hero is from the mountains. He can be very resistant to earth-attributed spells and attacks, as well as being very resistant to being confused. However, he is weak to water-attributed attacks and spells and the berserk condition.
To make these conditions and attributes able to be resisted (or otherwise), simply click on the letter next to it. It ranges from A to E, E being very weak to that condition or attribute, and A being very resistant to it.
You can create more attributes and conditions in the [[RPG_Maker_2003/Attribute|Attribute]] and [[RPG_Maker_2003/Condition|Condition]] tabs, which will be discussed later.
That is the end of the discussion of the hero tab in the Database. If you are ready to move on, please proceed to the [[RPG_Maker_2003/Class|Class]] section, and learn about classes so you can further your RPG education!
{{BookCat}}

[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Alinachka88!
{| cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="margin:0em 0em 1em 0em; width:100%" | style="width:55%; vertical-align:top; border:1px solid #fad67d; background-color:#faf6ed;" |

You don't need technical skills in order to contribute here. '''[[WB:BOLD|Be bold]]''' contributing here and ''[[WB:AGF|assume good faith]]'' for the intentions of others. Remember, this is a ''[[w:wiki|wiki]]'', so you're allowed to change just about anything, and changes can be made easily. Come [[WB:HELP|introduce yourself]] to everyone, and let us know what interests you.
[[Image:Icon apps query.svg|20px]] '''Getting help'''
* Remember, every edit is saved, so if you make mistakes, you can [[Help:How to revert a page to an earlier version|revert]] to an earlier version if needed. * Get help from the community in the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading room]] or in our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * We tag pages with various [[WB:TM|message templates]], such as {{tlx|query}}, to let editors know what needs to be improved. To learn more about these, ask at [[WB:PROJECTS|the projects reading room]]. * You cannot upload an image until you have been a member for at least '''4 days'''. If your upload is tagged with {{tlx|nld}}, {{tlx|bfu}}, or {{tlx|nfur}}, please read the template message as it explains the violation of [[WB:MEDIA|our media policy]]. Please be sure to provide the required {{tlx|information}}: a [[WB:ICT|license tag]] and source citation are always required; fair use images require a {{tlx|fair use rationale}}. Get help in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]]. | style="padding:0em 0.5em 0em 0.5em;" | | style="width:45%; vertical-align:top; border:1px solid #abd5f5; background-color:#f1f5fc;" |
[[Image:Transmission icon.png|20px]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please [[:w:Wikipedia:Sign your posts on talk pages|sign your name]] on discussion pages by typing ~~~~ * If you're coming here from Wikipedia, you should read [[WB:WFW|our primer for Wikipedians]] to get up-to-speed quickly. * '''Please make sure you follow our [[WB:NP|naming policy]]''' - modules should be named like Book Title/Chapter Title. * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
[[Image:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (only become available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To get a page deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason for requesting deletion''}} to the top of the page. * If something you wrote was deleted, please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:VFD|VFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:VFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.

Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?) |} == Copyright problems with [[:Image:Sequential model.jpg|Image:Sequential model.jpg]] == {{mbox|type=warning|msg= Thank you for uploading [[:Image:Sequential model.jpg|Image:Sequential model.jpg]]. However it is missing information needed for compliance with [[w:copyright|copyright law]] and Wikibooks' [[WB:MEDIA|media policy]]. This and other files you have uploaded may soon be deleted unless the '''copyright permissions''' and '''source''' can be determined. If you know this information, then please add the correct [[WB:ICT|templates]] to the [[:Image:Image:Sequential model.jpg|description page]] with the copyright and source information included; there is no need to upload it again. If you have any questions, feel free to contact me, or ask in the [[WB:HELP|assistance reading room]]. See {{UserImages}} for a complete list of your uploads which may get deleted soon.
Thank you. [[User:Abigor|Abigor]] ([[User talk:Abigor|talk]]) 13:39, 11 January 2009 (UTC)}}

Welcome to Beano's talk page.

----
Click [http://en.wikibooks.org/w/index.php?title=User_talk:Beano&action=edit§ion=new here] to message me. I will try to reply as soon as possible. All replies will be made on your talk page.

---- '''Please create your message with a subject/headline and sign your message using four tildes (~~~~) at the end.''' ---- '''People who must contact me immediately:''' You may want to consider messaging me on [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User_talk:Beano here] on my Wikipedia page. I spend most of my time there, and would be able to reply to your message in a more timely manner.

The username '''Kennedy''' has been usurped for my SUL account on '''27th November 2008'''.
If you were looking for the Kennedy before this date, you can contact them at [[User talk:Kennedy (usurped)]]
----
'''Important:''' I am not (yet?) active here, so if you need to speak to me, you can contact me at [http://simple.wikipedia.org/wiki/User:Kennedy my Simple.Wikipedia account.]
Regards, Kennedy

__NOTOC__ These boxes are collapsed by default. I am still figuring out how to fix this. Just click the arrows on the right side to expand each box.
When this username become autoconfirmed, I will change my templates and upload my picture.
image:Wikibar.png|64px| rect 0 0 0 0 [[Main page]] desc none
About Me
[[Image:Senior picture.jpg|thumb|Senior Picture - GO CLASS OF 07!]] My known internet name is BEANO, because of the fact I had really bad farts as a kid. It was like a weapon to me, since the gut-wrenching smell was good at keep my cousins from tackling me or doing anything little kids would do to others for fun. They would often make fun at me, saying that I needed to take the pill Beano, and the nickname eventually just stuck. People often call me that in place of my real name. I am currently 19 years old, and I live in Klamath Falls, Oregon. I grew up in Portland, Oregon and moved to Bend, Oregon in August 2001. Many people today would remember me as the little nerd from High Desert Middle School that fixed teachers' computers and solved network problems as an aide for the school administrator, or the short kid at BSH that took nerdy classes. I hung out with friends that many saw a nerdy, but friends that I saw that were great people who I still hang out with today. I currently work at Best Buy as a Geek Squad Agent. I am currently on O.S. and will be working there when I am not in school. It's a great job and I love it to death. I ran into Wikipedia my freshman year of High School, registered an account in 2005 and have been a member since. I started to get into fighting vandalism since around February 2007, and since then I have been getting more involved and more in-depth with Wikipedia. You may have seen me at least once somewhere, whether it's patrolling new pages and placing CSD tags, taking my part in discussions for AFD's, or giving users and IP's warnings for vandalism (and the like). It's kind of fun when you're bored and have nothing to do for the rest of the evening. Don't get me wrong, I didn't used to help maintain and expand Wikipedia. I went to a High School with five shared IPs that weren't static. I've had my laughs and fun times, but I decided to turn that foolish time around and do things the other direction. I have a username on this project because this username is a part of my SUL. You may not see me here as often, but I am working to expand my scope of work and eventually come out here to edit. When I'm not working, hanging out with friends or in school, I'm on the computer playing some videogames. I Love shooters and RPG's. My favorite kind of videogames are Strategy games. Starcraft has been my ultimate favorite game for going on ten years now. The first CD I bought was months after its release, and it says on the CD that it is for "Windows 95 / MAC". I can't wait till SC2! I was heavily involved in playing computer games. I have 6 level 20 characters on Guild Wars and all of the expansions, and played a lot of Counter Strike: Source, Team Fortress 2, and Call of Duty 4. I haven't played Guild Wars, CS:S, or TF2 since I started school. I'm trying to keep away from "commitment requiring" games so that I can focus on college and keep good grades. I'll be back to playing full-time in the summer... and maybe StarCraft 2 when it comes out :-)
image:Wikibar.png|64px| rect 0 0 0 0 [[Main page]] desc none
Computers and Education
{{Userboxtop|General Stuff}} {{Userboxbottom}} I graduated from Bend High School in 2007, and I am working and attending college. I am attending Oregon Institute of Technology|OIT with credits transferred from COCC. I am in a double major program (Computer Hardware Engineering / Computer Software Engineering) with a mathematics minor. Computers have always been my life and passion. At 5, I got my hands on my first computer. A Compaq computer with an old Pentium processor and 48MB of RAM. I played many old computer games... Rebel Assault II, Dark Forces, Starcraft, etc. At 9, I was already installing programs, upgrading Windows from 95 to 98, and teaching my parents how to do things they didn't know could be done with a computer. I built my first computer at 12 years old. It was just a Pentium II Processor, but it marked a lot of achievement for me since I did it on my own. I was a computer tech aide for two years at my Middle School, and for three additional years at my High School thereafter. I today, have a pretty decent machine built (see Computer Specs below). I have built many computers for others that wanted a custom built computer, and have been paid countless times for computer repair services. ===Computer Specs=== *Intel Core 2 Duo E6750 *Asus P5N-T Deluxe 780i motherboard *4 GB Corsair XMS2 DDR2 RAM *Nvidia GeForce 8800 GT 512MB X2 (In SLI Mode) *Thermaltake a1 professional series fan *Thermaltake armor case (Revision 1.0a) *Antec 600 Watt PSU *Windows Vista Ultimate *Sony DVD-RW Drives X 2 *Floppy drive Any questions about my computer, or computers in general can be asked [[User_Talk:Beano|here]]. I don't mind helping people out that have problems.
image:Wikibar.png|64px| rect 0 0 0 0 [[Main page]] desc none
Messaging Beano
{{{icon|[[Image:Information.svg|30px|left]] }}} Need to send me a message? Click [http://en.wikinews.org/w/wiki.phtml?title=User_talk:Beano&action=edit§ion=new '''here''']!
Please leave a subject and sign your message with four tildes (~~~~) at the end so I can easily identify you.

==English to Latin==
This should be the first thing you do. Find a random English sentence. Any sentence is ok. Then you should think about the sounds that exist within the sentence. We are only concerned about sounds, not meaning at this point. Your task is to rewrite the sentence writing only the sounds that are in it. If the sentence has sounds in it that do not exist in the Latin language, change the sound to a sound, any sound, that is close. For example, the most common word in the English language is the word "the"; however, the '''TH''' sound does not exist in Latin, so you have to change it to a sound that does exist in Latin, since keeping the ''TH'' spelling will not work as that will produce just a '''T''' sound. A '''D''' sound is much closer and is probably what you should use. Also, when you come across the '''a''' sound in English words like '''cat''' you should keep in mind that this sound does not exist in Latin so you will have to choose between a Latin '''A''' or a Latin '''E''' as the sound is somewhere between them.
Here is an example.
"Billy went to the store to buy some apples."
The sounds that don't exist in Latin are as follows.
"B'''i'''lly '''w'''ent to '''th'''e sto'''r'''e to buy some '''a'''pples."
And here is how it looks using only Latin letters and being spelled exaclty as it sounds.
"Bili uent tu da (di) stor (stoa) tu bai sam apols (epols)."
==Sound it out==
Remember that Latin is supposed to be spelled exactly as it sounds. We do not memorize a spelling that does not match the pronunciation. We memorize the pronunciation and that pronunciation controls the spelling. So now that you have the basics and have even converted some English into just sounds, it is now time to see sounds written and for you to sound it out. Don't be worried if you do not know what these words mean. They are put here for you to see the sounds and to practice your pronunciation. You can look the words up yourself later or just wait as we will cover this very often used prayer in a later lesson. In this example, remember to pronounce the Latin '''A''' as the English short '''o''' sound, this seems to be the most common beginner mistake when saying this prayer.
'''Gloria Patri et Filio et Spiritui Sancto; sicut erat in principio, et nunc, et semper, et in saecula saeculorum. Amen.'''
Note: the '''ae''' will sound as just '''e'''. Also, unlike in English where a '''T''' followed by an '''r''' will create the '''ch''' sound, Latin does not do this. The '''T''' and the '''R''' are individually pronounced. If you blend these into a '''ch''' sound it means that you are not pronouncing your '''R''' correctly and need to listen to a cat '''purrrrrr''' for a bit to get the sound right. If you pronounce your '''R''' correctly, then you will not feel the urge to blend the '''T''' and the '''R'''.
This prayer is used very often in Catholic life when we pray the rosary, the psalms in the Liturgy of the Hours, and many other times as well. Interestingly, it is not used in the Mass in its current form, but is still very common for any Catholic who maintains a private prayer life in addition to Mass.

[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Catalysis!
{| cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="margin:0em 0em 1em 0em; width:100%" | style="width:55%; vertical-align:top; border:1px solid #fad67d; background-color:#faf6ed;" |
[[Image:Crystal Clear app korganizer.png|20px]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for freely-licensed collaboratively-developed [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].'''
You don't need technical skills in order to contribute here. '''[[WB:BOLD|Be bold]]''' contributing here and ''[[WB:AGF|assume good faith]]'' for the intentions of others. Remember, this is a ''[[w:wiki|wiki]]'', so you're allowed to change just about anything, and changes can be made easily. Come [[WB:HELP|introduce yourself]] to everyone, and let us know what interests you.
[[Image:Icon apps query.svg|20px]] '''Getting help'''
* Remember, every edit is saved, so if you make mistakes, you can [[Help:How to revert a page to an earlier version|revert]] to an earlier version if needed. * Get help from the community in the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading room]] or in our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * We tag pages with various [[WB:TM|message templates]], such as {{tlx|query}}, to let editors know what needs to be improved. To learn more about these, ask at [[WB:PROJECTS|the projects reading room]]. * You cannot upload an image until you have been a member for at least '''4 days'''. If your upload is tagged with {{tlx|nld}}, {{tlx|bfu}}, or {{tlx|nfur}}, please read the template message as it explains the violation of [[WB:MEDIA|our media policy]]. Please be sure to provide the required {{tlx|information}}: a [[WB:ICT|license tag]] and source citation are always required; fair use images require a {{tlx|fair use rationale}}. Get help in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]]. | style="padding:0em 0.5em 0em 0.5em;" | | style="width:45%; vertical-align:top; border:1px solid #abd5f5; background-color:#f1f5fc;" |
[[Image:Transmission icon.png|20px]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please [[:w:Wikipedia:Sign your posts on talk pages|sign your name]] on discussion pages by typing ~~~~ * If you're coming here from Wikipedia, you should read [[WB:WFW|our primer for Wikipedians]] to get up-to-speed quickly. * '''Please make sure you follow our [[WB:NP|naming policy]]''' - modules should be named like Book Title/Chapter Title. * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
[[Image:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (only become available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To get a page deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason for requesting deletion''}} to the top of the page. * If something you wrote was deleted, please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:VFD|VFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:VFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
Thanks  '''— [[User:Mike.lifeguard|Mike.lifeguard]]''' | [[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|talk]] 03:41, 27 November 2008 (UTC)
|- |align=right colspan=3|(P.S. Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?) |}
